4.22.19  10:50 pm   I have decided to compile a list of my very favorite 320 songs that all have something about them that I really want to learn.  I plan to learn as much of the list as I can in 3 months with a focus on performability (can I perform it for an audience comfortably?), assimilating elements (am i making any sense of what is going on?), and perhaps a little bit of content if I'm lucky.  I'm putting this deadline because this is a deadly serious thing that i've probably been needing to do for awhile but I have been swamped with trying to figure out how to make content. But i'm afraid if i don't do this my content and my position as a musician will not grow nearly at the exponential rate that it might if i just do this project and use the powers afterwards.  i just don't want to die taking forever to do it. Does this sound like a good plan to you?  Any tips, tricks, or advice?

html:
4.21.19  10:39 pm   4.21.19  1:25 am what do you mean by improvising the lyrics?

      For your own songs? Other songs? Any songs?

      And what do you find beneficial about this?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201904210125

4.21.19  1:25 am   let's say that i desperately wanna make my own music, just as you are, but i have absolutely no experience in making my voice sound remotely good. i've got good ears and pitch and everything, but the voice just sounds bad and the technique is nonexistent. how do you think i could at least get my voice to a good baseline which i could expand on throughout my life, in like a solid two months?
i know "just do it a lot" is a great answer here, but how do i "just do it" well enough that i can make solid progress along with that? i think i know how this works for physical instruments which i can observe the mechanics of in front of my eyes, but the voice is too obscure, where should i even start? i can feel myself dipping into that 13th level of suffering

     this is similar to what i went through, because i am working from the same starting point as you. but you will already be better after 1 month. and at 2 months you will be a little better. and at 3 months you will be better. so the 'baseline' you are working with is actually right now, that's your starting point. 2 months from now will be the middle. unless you stop singing entirely after 2 months.
     for specifics on technique, for some reason no professional vocal technical advice ever made any sense to me until many years later, and much of it still doesn't. i found that the voice is so deeply connected with life itself that it was almost impossible for me to think directly about most of the things professionals tell you to think about. so i had to find much more abstract tricks. one of the most important tricks i learned was to improvise the lyrics. and for scripted material, try to do it like you are terrified of joe jackson whipping you
original_html:

     for specifics on technique, for some reason no professional vocal technical advice ever made any sense to me until many years later, and much of it still doesn't. i found that the voice is so deeply connected with life itself that it was almost impossible for me to think directly about most of the things professionals tell you to think about. so i had to find much more abstract tricks. one of the most important tricks i learned was to improvise the lyrics. and for scripted material, try to do it like you are terrified of joe jackson whipping you
